; Mon, 20 Nov 2023 15:25:03 +0800 “永恒”的敌人：未了案横跨八十年，谁的“王洛宾”？http://www.infzm.com/contents/260885
;;2023-11-20 14:00:00;
;

;;

;

;September 11, 2023, Zhuozhou, Hebei Province, Wang Haicheng's manuscript of "In That Distant Place". (Southern Weekend reporter Su Youpeng/Photo)

;

;A stage play

;

;;Only a few people realize that everything they enjoy at the moment is facing unprecedented challenges. ;

;

;A quarter of an hour before 7:30, outside the West Second Ring Road in Beijing, a group of children and parents gathered in front of the Erqi Theater. It was a cool evening in early September, and the new version of the red children's drama "The Ballad of Soybean" began its national tour here.

;

;Some Chinese people are familiar with this story. In 1940, the Gansu Provincial Working Committee of the Communist Party of China was destroyed. Luo Lili, who was 8 months old, was arrested at the same time as his parents. After several twists and turns, he was imprisoned in Lanzhou Dashagou Prison, where he spent 6 years. Wang Luobin, who was also in prison, asked Luo Lili what the most delicious food in the world was. Luo Lili, who had never been exposed to the outside world, thought it was broad beans that he had eaten by chance. Wang Luobin composed the song "Soybean Ballad" from this.

;

;A while after leaving the venue, the crowd suddenly surrounded an old man.

;

;The old man has appeared on CCTV 13 times. On TV, he is smart, wise, and tall. He is proud that he "didn't make a single mistake" when talking. ", and sometimes, I even have to play and sing "In That Distant Place" on the stage.

;

;But the old man in front of him has droopy eye bags and a lot of white hair on his sparse head. He kept taking out performance tickets from the small shoulder bag on his chest, a total of 40 tickets, which belonged to "old friends" he had met through cooperation in the name of his father.

;

;Most of these "old friends" reached the peak of their careers in the 1990s. They had their own programs in top media and were able to open solo concerts in the most central concert hall in Beijing. Concert, organize a commemorative concert for Wang Luobin in the most famous building.

;

;There are also officials from Zhuozhou, Hebei. This county-level city with a population of 650,000 has a 30-square-meter former residence of Wang Luobin and a Wang Luobin Chorus. The director of Zhuozhou Culture and Tourism Bureau and the director of the cultural center drove 60 kilometers to come.

;

;He is the youngest son of Wang Luobin, the "King of Western Singers". Wang Luobin's ancestral home is in Zhuozhou, and a new Wang Luobin Music Memorial Hall is about to be renovated in an old factory in the north of the city as a local cultural landmark.

;

;Wang Luobin, who will appear on the stage in a quarter of an hour, is a "prisoner" who has to go through several political movements before he can be called the King of Singers in the future. , Prison Years, and Social Change.

;

;Wang Luobin's 83-year ups and downs often give playwrights a headache. He once participated in the Northwest Anti-Japanese War Theater Troupe with Xiao Jun, Seke and others. He was also highly appreciated by the warlord Ma Bufang and formed a children's theater troupe in Qinghai. During China's darkest period, he captured a hint of romanticism, and some of the songs he was most proud of in his life were born here, including "In That Distant Place" and "Youth Dance."

;

;At half past seven, "Soybean Ballad" started. I got a chance to film Wang Haicheng, a documentary director who has been following him for more than ten years. The film is called "Looking for Wang Luobin".

;

;For the "old friends" in the audience, some people want to promote this drama to a bigger stage, and some people want to make a movie related to Wang Luobin. , two people respectively proposed to build a music school named after the king of singers in Hebei and Hainan.

;

;They all need to obtain authorization from Wang Haicheng. Only a few people realize that everything the son of the King of Songs enjoys at the moment is facing unprecedented challenges.

;

;;

;

;September 11, 2023 On the same day, in Zhuozhou, Hebei Province, Wang Haicheng displayed his published biography of Wang Luobin and audio-visual products. (Southern Weekend reporter Su Youpeng/Photo)

;

;SON OF THE SINGER

;

;;Family has never been a place where the singer is willing to devote his attention;

;

;Wang Haicheng has spent half his life defending his father's honor.

;

;Wang Luobin has two marriages, three sons and several loves. Among the three sons, the eldest went to Australia in the 1980s. The second child was a truck driver and died of illness. After surviving a period of history, the four fathers and sons now only have the third child left. Therefore, interviews, authorizations, rights protection, concerts, commemorations, and publications all fell on Wang Haicheng.

;

;In fact, for a long time, the identity of "Wang Luobin's son" made Wang Haicheng breathless. When he was 8 months old, Wang Luobin was arrested, followed by a search of his home. A month later, his mother passed away in the hospital bed. Relatives in Beijing did not dare to have contact with the Wang family. After hearing about it, the fifth uncle in Zhuozhou drove a carriage all day and night from Beijing in the early winter in the north to bring the body back from Beijing and bury it in a wheat field.

;

;A few years ago, Wang Haicheng tried to find his mother's tomb, but he could no longer find it.

;

;Studying stopped in the second grade of junior high school. When it was time to go to the mountains and countryside, Wang Haicheng stayed on the farm for nine years because of Wang Luobin. When groups of educated young people returned to the city one after another, he also got a nickname: "Cushionzi". This dialect refers to the last puppy out of a litter.

;

;Family is never a place where the singer is willing to devote his attention. Wang Haicheng wrote that the union between his father and his mother was due to the breakup of his father's previous relationship, so he wanted to take revenge on his life. Wang Luobin was born free. He went to the grassland, to the market, and even in prison, collecting folk songs. A producer who visited the singer's deeds mentioned a detail. In his later years, Wang Luobin rode a bicycle everywhere. When it got dark, he would lie on the road and fall asleep, and then go home the next day.

;

;Wang Luobin passed away in 1996. Wang Haicheng immediately joined the China Music Copyright Association and registered 207 musical works recorded, organized and created by Wang Luobin with the association. He became increasingly aware that his father had left a shining legacy. Since 2000, Wang Haicheng has successively published two biographies of Wang Luobin, a song sheet of Wang Luobin, invested in TV films, and a long narrative poem. Four exhibition halls have been created in Turpan, Xinjiang, Haibei, Qinghai, Baishui Ancient Town, Dabancheng, Xinjiang, and Liupan Mountain, Ningxia.

;

;It is difficult to say how father's love plays a subtle role in Wang Haicheng's life. In order to guard this heritage, he was like an ascetic, stationed in the Grape Valley of the Flame Mountain for 16 years.

;

;In the first few years of the 21st century, the Turpan Wang Luobin Music and Art Museum in Grape Valley was the only temple to commemorate the king of singers. This building has an Ottoman-style white circular dome and 80 panels displaying the singer's life. Visitors came in the 40℃ high temperature. When they opened the door, they saw the sweaty son of the singer wearing a shirt with Wang Luobin's logo in front of him. There were biographies, song collections, tapes and records on the counter. When the operation of the art museum was most difficult, Wang Haicheng went to bring in strange stones from the Gobi Desert that looked like pork belly and English letters. This is the most popular commodity in Xinjiang’s tourism market.

;

;He also set up an incense burner in front of his father's portrait - Wang Luobin converted to Buddhism in his later years. There was once a man who claimed to be a physicist and kowtowed three times directly to the portrait.

;

;Wang Haicheng honed his speaking skills, pondered the details of his father's life, paid attention to his image, and never refused any opportunity to appear in the national media. The comment that moved him most came from an old man from Shandong: "Wang Haicheng, you are the biggest filial son in China."

;

;;

;

;On July 24, 2022, Wang Luobin Music Art Museum is located in Grape Valley, Turpan, Xinjiang. (Visual China/Picture)

;

;Salvage and Debate

;

;;Changing one note, two notes, or a chorus counts as "adaptation"? ;

;

;In the 1990s, a modern storm swept through Urumqi: the most cutting-edge local popular music came from further west. Ethnic minorities hold weekly house music gatherings. Seven days and nights after the song "Forgetting Love Water" reached Urumqi, the shops in the Grand Bazaar would use rough-sounding speakers to play versions in other languages. The bars all over the street are full of singing bands. On the radio, the male host can talk endlessly about the Beatles, Tchaikovsky and Rachmaninoff.

;

;Yibo, the director of "Looking for Wang Luobin", was the popular host of the Urumqi Economic Radio program "Music Leisure Island" at the time. After more than 20 years, she believes that Urumqi at that time showed tolerance for all kinds of music and was the "center of Asian music."

;

;But there is no local singer's name in popular music. His limelight comes from outside Urumqi.

;

;Wang Luobin was rediscovered in the context of an era where order was brought to order. In May 1981, on an afternoon when the temperature suddenly soared to 33°C and the snow suddenly melted, in a five- to six-square-meter concierge at the Qianjin Theater, Xinhua News Agency reporter Zhao Quanzhang met Wang Luobin, who had just been released from prison. In Zhao Quanzhang's reminiscence article, this person who looked like Quasimodo in "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" was unemployed, had no household registration, and did not even have "food and oil connections."

;

;Zhao Quanzhang wrote the internal reference for Wang Luobin, and soon received instructions from Song Renqiong, then head of the Organization Department of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China. Zhao Quanzhang once recalled that the work of bringing order to the country was not completely smooth at that time. The resolution of Wang Luobin's problem had an impact on Xinjiang and the whole country.

;

;Openness was the theme of the 1980s. And for a musician who has experienced the war of resistance, prison, and rehabilitation, is there any symbol more suitable to glimpse a country's path of exploration?

;

;In the autumn of 1988, "Eight Thousand Miles to the Clouds and the Moon" hosted by Taiwanese artist Ling Feng went to Xinjiang to interview Wang Luobin. This was the first program from the other side to introduce China. TV programs about mainland China’s customs and customs. Then, Xia Jie, a female writer from Hong Kong, China, also came to visit and wrote three articles. Soon, Singapore, Australia, North America, and overseas Chinese had someone to pay attention to.

;

;The media calls him the King of Western Singers and enjoys special government subsidies. China Record Corporation awarded him the Golden Record Special Creation Award, and UNESCO awarded him the "Promote "Special Contribution Award for Cultural Exchange between East and West". But all medals are inferior to the gifts given by the people. In the era when the word "fan" only refers to fans, Wang Luobin's most proud example is, "Chinese friends said that at least half of the two million Chinese in the United States can sing. "In that distant place"".

;

;A more well-known story is that Sanmao, a female writer from Taiwan, China, moved directly into the home of the singer, and scandals abounded.

;

;Trouble is coming quietly. One day in 1993, Luo Dayou's agent called. Not long ago, Rolling Stone Records released the tape "Love Song Anniversary - Luo Dayou and Wang Luobin's Great Collaboration of the Century" without Wang Luobin's consent. The King of Songs was very angry and took Luo Dayou to court for infringement of his copyright.

;

;Greater controversy ensued. Someone revealed that Ling Feng paid 20,000 yuan to buy out ten of Wang Luobin's songs, including "In That Faraway Place", "The Girl from Dabancheng", "Mayila" and "Youth Dance".

;

;The music issue soon turned into a political issue. Someone asked, can Wang Luobin sell folk songs that belong to the people?

;

;A major discussion that lasted for more than a year began. In June 1994, "People's Music" magazine began to discuss the copyright issue of Wang Luobin's folk songs. Dai Penghai, an associate researcher at the Shanghai Conservatory of Music, published two articles criticizing the news media for hyping up Wang Luobin, and also accused Wang Luobin of "selling out the people's sovereignty and interests in national music culture."

;

;There are also people who support Wang Luobin. Liu Zaisheng, a professor at the Music Department of Shandong Normal University, pointed out that “collecting brotherly ethnic songs in different languages ​​is a more complex and difficult task, and the translation and dubbing of lyrics often plays a key role in success or failure.” And “if we combine the When the lyrics are analyzed together, it is not difficult to find that they have formed Wang Luobin's unique creative style that is lyrical, colloquial, and popular."

;

;Another background to the great discussion is that during China's "resumption of customs" negotiations, the Copyright Law was promulgated in 1991, which stipulates that "adaptation, translation, The copyright of works resulting from the annotation and arrangement of existing works shall be enjoyed by the person who adapted, translated, annotated and arranged them." In other words, if Wang Luobin "adapts, translates, annotates, and organizes" folk songs, the copyright of the new songs belongs to him.

;

;But, does changing one note, two notes, or a chorus count as "adaptation"?

;

;On August 5 of that year, a symposium attended by more than thirty people was held in Beijing, including musicologists, composers, and legal professionals. people and journalists. The person presiding over the meeting was Qiao Jianzhong, then director of the Music Research Institute of the China Academy of Arts. He later recalled in an article that this symposium was actually an "absent criticism" against Wang Luobin, which was very explosive. However, the meeting finally reached a consensus that Wang Luobin had worked hard in recording, translating, editing, and adapting folk songs, but the rights he enjoyed needed to be quantitatively analyzed before the rights could be determined.

;

;The eighty-year-old singer was very hurt and left the stage to participate in the debate in person several times.

;

;With the death of Wang Luobin in 1996, the big discussion did not continue. But this discussion could have clarified some fundamental issues, such as the quantitative standards for adaptation and the copyright of folk songs. In that era, Wang Luobin was not the only one who encountered similar problems.

;

;In Shanghai, a young man who was writing "The Complete Works of Xian Xinghai" was also troubled by this problem. In the process of sorting out Xian Xinghai's works, Wu Yuebei, a top student in the composition department of the Shanghai Conservatory of Music, checked and filled in the original scores. Some melodies that he thought were not harmonious even needed to be changed. When Xian Xinghai's descendants heard about Wang Luobin's dispute, they worriedly asked, if the original score was adjusted, would the copyright belong to him?

;

;After consulting the leaders of the Ministry of Culture at the time, "The Complete Works of Xian Xinghai" was finally processed as follows: the works with major changes were also included in the revised original works. version, as well as a more substantial adapted version. For revised or revised editions, the name of the reviser will be marked as a footnote at the end of the work, but no copyright will be generated. The edited version will have a copyright page marked with the name of the organizer, who owns the rights to the content compiled by him in the new version, but not the rights to the original work.

;

;This young man majoring in composition has no way of knowing that after more than 20 years, he may end the discussion about the copyright of the singer.

;

;;

;

;Wang Luobin and Luo Dayou. Reproduced from the photo album saved by Wang Haicheng on September 11, 2023. (Southern Weekend reporter Su Youpeng/Photo)

;

;Carpet rights protection

;

;;His opponents include video city vendors, publishing houses, university professors, as well as Li Yuchun, Tan Weiwei and Wang Sulong. ;

;

;The new century is coming, and the law has become a modern weapon to protect rights and interests. Wang Haicheng suddenly discovered that everything his father left behind could be easily taken away.

;

;At that time, China was in the midst of a heat wave to achieve modernization through a market economy. The "resumption of customs" turned into "joining the WTO", a stable and international The integrated legal system is gradually improving. Intellectual property rights are a focus.

;

;In 2002, Wang Luobin's adaptation of "Tall White Poplar" was sued by the family of a deceased musician for copyright infringement. The family members believe that "Tall White Poplar" is not a folk song, but a song composed by the late musician, originally titled "How Beautiful My Garden is."

;

;The family did not sue Wang Haicheng directly, but first sued an audio-visual company in Guangzhou. The CD published by the company labeled "Tall White Poplar" as a folk song. The court found that the song was composed by the late musician. Afterwards, the family took this judgment and sued Wang Haicheng, claiming 230,000 yuan.

;

;Wang Haicheng said that "Tall White Poplar" was written by his father in 1969 while serving a sentence. At that time, a young man was unjustly imprisoned, and his new wife died. The young man stopped cutting his hair and shaving. Wang Luobin felt inspired and adapted "Tall White Poplar" based on an Ili folk song.

;

;A friend in Yili told Wang Haicheng that the original version of this ancient folk song can be found in the local archives. But before he was about to leave, the friend said that the information was missing.

;

;In August 2004, the court of first instance sentenced Wang Haicheng to pay compensation of 237,000 yuan.

;

;After the appeal, Wang Haicheng and his lawyer began to think about how to collect evidence. In October 2005, he and his lawyer pretended to be collectors from Beijing and spent 4,600 yuan to buy a small video camera. After arriving in Yili, they arranged to grab mutton and invited local music teachers and old people who could sing folk songs for interviews. At first, they did not reveal their interest in "Tall White Poplar" and started talking about Ili folk songs. The cameras are always working.

;

;After the conversation was almost over, Wang Haicheng turned to "Tall White Poplar" and asked if there was an original folk song version of this song. Everyone said yes, and everyone hummed a line.

;

;But when they reveal their identities, very few people are willing to testify.

;

;After hitting a wall one after another, they finally found three old people willing to testify. I also met an "Avanti" (meaning "teacher") named Ishamuddin, who said that the original song had probably been circulated for two hundred years, and he also knew that a lawsuit was ongoing.

;

;At that time, Wang Haicheng thought that if he lost the lawsuit, "things would develop like dominoes." Dozens of publishers had published this song Society will also be in crisis. Even if he travels to Hainan, he will pray with Mazu, hoping that Mazu can help him, the son of the king of singers, who is in trouble.

;

;On May 8, 2006, the Xinjiang High Court made a judgment that the two songs each enjoyed property rights in copyright. In Wang Haicheng's words, "Both songs come from folk songs, and they are in a parallel relationship."

;

;At almost the same time, Wang Haicheng launched a blanket rights protection campaign that lasted for several years. For the sake of copyright, he fought against pirated CDs, KTV bosses, and singers who randomly covered his father's works. His opponents include audio-visual city vendors, publishers, university professors, as well as Li Yuchun, Tan Weiwei and Wang Sulong.

;

;It was in 2004 when he was ordered to pay 237,000 yuan in compensation that Wang Haicheng received an unfamiliar phone call. The other party introduced himself like this: Ju Yonghe, a native of Jiangsu, a lawyer in Beijing, and a loyal fan of Wang Luobin.

;

;When they finally met a year later, Wang Haicheng was deeply impressed by his "uprightness and non-joking".

;

;"He said that he was concerned that there were many publications infringing Wang Luobin's rights on the market, and he especially wanted to help protect his rights." Wang Haicheng was "a little nervous financially at the time, and he was also weighing Should I file a lawsuit?" Lawyer Ju dispelled his concerns: He would bear the cost of the lawsuit. If he lost the lawsuit, he would not ask Wang Haicheng for money. If he won, he would pay half of it after deducting travel expenses.

;

;This may be a more subtle way, and it also uses legal weapons to confirm again and again that Wang Luobin owns the copyright to a certain song.

;

;Since 2005, Lawyer Ju has continued to make efforts. He went to the audio and video market and Xinhua Bookstore, walked around, saw the allegedly infringing publications, bought them, issued invoices, and sued. "All those audio and video publishers came to me to ask for authorization. They can also use high-definition pictures of Wang Luobin on the covers of their publications. I also provided the introduction of Wang Luobin on the inside pages. It is more accurate and the text is smoother.";

;Wang Luobin became an inviolable icon. Around 2010, Lawyer Ju moved to KTV. In the words of the time, it was a "mopping up" operation. KTV's infringement made Wang Haicheng even more intolerable. The scenes in "In That Distant Place" were of Hainan beaches and bikini beauties.

;

;Based on the Yangtze River Delta, Lawyer Ju gradually expanded the scope of his operations. In his eyes, "the judicial environment in the Yangtze River Delta was relatively good at the time."

;

;Victory is like a snowball getting bigger and bigger. In the eyes of some people in the music industry, even if it didn't belong to him before, it belongs to him now.

;

;According to Wang Haicheng, the economic benefits in this round were not as much as people imagined. The compensation involved in the case that he received was "about 120,000 yuan." ". But he is very happy and feels that this battle is going smoothly and "the pirated KTVs have been beaten into silence."

;

;In this battle, he gave himself an indestructible meaning: to maintain his father's eternal status in the history of Chinese music.

;

;But this blanket rights protection came to an abrupt end in 2013, and Wang Haicheng was put in a tight ring. After mediation by the Supreme People's Court, Wang Luobin's descendants reached an agreement: some of the previous lawsuits should be withdrawn. "If the lawsuit cannot be withdrawn, the accepting authority should proactively notify the accepting agency to add Wang Haiyan (eldest brother) and Wang Haixing (second brother) as co-litigants. ;Ethnomusicology began in 1959. Kunst, a Dutch musicologist who was stationed in Java for 15 years, renamed the third edition of his book "Musicology" to "Ethnomusicology", thereby creating this discipline.

;"Those who have studied Kazakh folk songs can tell that these are not folk songs. Why? Kazakh folk songs have a specific rhythm, and a song is divided into a verse and a chorus. There are two parts. The lyrics of the main song must be 11 syllables, and their combinations can be 344, 443, or 434. Each combination is a musical step." Du Yaxiong said, "There is another rule, that is, the combination of lyrics and music does not match. Generally, The lyrics and music are consistent. However, one phrase of the Kazakh folk song has ended, but the words have not yet been sung. The last step of the first phrase must be put into the second phrase to sing; or the first phrase must be used. Sing the first note of the second line of the lyrics in the last section."

;

;"Nomads have an exchange mechanism. Young people will not stay in tents all the time and go to herd sheep. ;Du Yaxiong understands Kazakh. After many inquiries, he finally found the author of "Dudar and Maria" and "Mayila".

;

;The author of the first song is Maria Jagger (1887-1950), who was born in Akmola, Kazakhstan. People's Artist of Stan. Du Yaxiong concluded that she composed this song around 1903. This song is widely circulated in Kazakhstan and has been the theme of many musical works. Judging from the time recorded by Wang Luobin, this song was introduced to China in the early 1930s at the latest.

;

;The author of the second song is Mayila Shamsuttinova (1890-1927), a professor at the Almaty Conservatory of Music. Mati Zhubanov once introduced this person in the book "The Nightingale of the Times" and said that this song is the author's "self-portrait".

;

;Du Yaxiong also researched "The Girl from Dabancheng". He went to Turpan to find the original version of this song and found that the local version was weak and Syncopated rhythm. He was curious about why Wang Luobin's version was not like this. Wang Luobin's statement was that the driver he heard sang it was like this - not that Wang Haicheng said that he actively changed it to a version suitable for Han people.

;

;About "Youth Dance", Wang Luobin told Du Yaxiong: "It was recorded in Dongguan, Jiuquan in 1939. The lyrics are the original ones, not compiled by me. ”

;

;As for "Crown Pearl", Du Yaxiong does not think that the popular version is the result of being "out of tune", but a version with a male accent, using " "Reverse tune" technique to create a female accent.

;

;Therefore, in the 1983 "Selected Songs of Luobin", Du Yaxiong divided the songs into two parts, the first part was folk songs, and the second part was Wang Luobin's Creation, and these songs are all in the first part.

;

;However, Du Yaxiong also affirmed Wang Luobin's contribution in translating minority languages, "Even if I can write songs in minority languages, it is difficult to translate the lyrics It is too difficult to translate it into Chinese, and the translation must be faithful, elegant and expressive. Of course, some things are no longer correct from the original, so he is half-edited and half-translated."

;

;In fact, in the final judgment of the Beijing Intellectual Property Court, Wang Haicheng still achieved partial victory. The court found that Wang Luobin and his descendants continued to enjoy the copyright of lyrics and music for "Dabancheng Girl", "Dudar and Maria", "Maira" and "In That Faraway Place"; for "Youth Dance", they also enjoyed the copyright of lyrics.

;

;But Wang Haicheng still believes that someone is accelerating this disappearance. Not long ago, when Beijing Normal University was producing the musical "The Ballad of the Past," someone suggested that "In That Faraway Place" might be controversial. The school conveyed that it was reported by a lawyer.

;

;The lawyer's name is Dong Xiaoyue, and she is Chen Tianhe's granddaughter. She also has a persistent life. When I was holding a chorus competition in high school, a classmate mentioned that "In That Far Far Place" belonged to Wang Luobin and she would scratch her. Chen Tianhe passed away in 1955.

;

;Dong Xiaoyue, who was born in the 1980s, worked as a reporter and book editor, but this matter has troubled her from time to time. Around 2010, she began to look for "Selected Chinese Folk Songs" by the Folk Song Society in major libraries in Beijing. The earliest version of this book only had two volumes in China. She finally found it in the internal library of the Music Research Institute of the China Academy of Arts. .

;

;Just like the result of a life experience, Dong Xiaoyue became a lawyer.

;

;Someone once asked her to collect copyright fees. She replied in a letter: "We should no longer be entangled in copyright disputes and let everything go. Music issues do not need to be left to the law."

;

;Wang Luobin, a young man more than eighty years ago, would not have thought that the copyright and origin of a song could be so far away that It's going to be so important in the future.

;

;In 1935, at the age of 22, he worked as a music teacher in a middle school outside Xizhimen, Beijing. There was a river nearby, and he would go swimming in the river at noon in the summer. There were also many college students who migrated after the fall of Northeast China. One day, people with bare buttocks and covered in mud were listening to their classmates read "August Village". This novel describes the story of the Northeast soldiers and civilians fighting against the Japanese invaders after the "September 18th" Incident. When he read a poem called "I want love, I also want the freedom of my motherland", the passionate Wang Luobin put on his clothes, copied the poem, and went home to compose music.

;

;Later, a young man came and said that he wrote and sang well, but did he know who the author of the novel was. Wang Luobin was embarrassed and didn't know the answer. The young man laughed and said, "The author is Xiao Jun, and I am Xiao Jun." Wang Luobin recalled: "I was shocked, so the two of us hugged and laughed, and we became friends."

;Chronology of Wang Luobin
;

;;Born in Beijing in 1913. ;

;

;In 1931, he entered the Music Department of National Beiping Normal University to study.

;

;In 1937, when the Anti-Japanese War broke out, he went to Shanxi to join the Eighth Route Army Northwest Field Service Corps.

;

;In 1940, he worked as a music educator in Xining, Qinghai, and was responsible for the establishment of the Qinghai Children's Anti-Japanese War Troupe.

;

;In 1949, he joined the Chinese People's Liberation Army.

;

;From 1952 to 1976, he was imprisoned many times.

;

;In 1981, he was rehabilitated and his honor and military status were restored, and he served as the art consultant of the Xinjiang Military Region Art Troupe.

;

;In 1991, he enjoyed special government subsidies.

;

;In 1994, he was awarded the Special Contribution Award for East-West Cultural Exchange by UNESCO.

;

;In 1996, he died of gallbladder adenocarcinoma at the age of 83.
